clean_text: APT-99 likely initiated operations by querying a paid threat intelligence feed to gather intelligence on the target's email infrastructure and subsequently sent a phishing email disguised as a password reset request from the IT department to gather victim identity information. The malware then queried the company's 'About Us' page to collect employee names for spear-phishing, while the threat actor uploaded a PowerShell backdoor script to a private GitHub repository for later retrieval. In the next phase, Lumma Stealer was delivered through phishing emails containing malicious links, and the malware leveraged SCCM to run a PowerShell script that collected system information from connected workstations. APT42 has used the PowerShell-based POWERPOST script to collect local account names from the victim machine, and the attacker used WinRM to remotely execute commands on the target Windows system. LuminousMoth has used ARP spoofing to redirect a compromised machine to an actor-controlled website, and WARPWIRE can capture credentials submitted during the web logon process to access layer seven applications such as RDP. The adversary used PowerShell to query IMAP servers for email metadata, and Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can change C2 servers. Sibot communicated with its C2 server via HTTP GET requests, while OpenSSL encrypted the collected network topology maps before transmission. Finally, the ransomware extracted sensitive_docs.zip from the network share before encryption. System logs from the target environment showed routine backup processes and user login attempts, which were unrelated to the attack. The company, a mid-sized financial services firm, had recently updated its firewall policies, but this did not prevent the initial breach.

llm_raw_response.title: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory: Fictional APT Campaign Targeting Corporate Networks
llm_raw_response.summary: This advisory details a simulated campaign by a fictional advanced persistent threat (APT) group, designated as APT-99, targeting corporate networks for data exfiltration and credential theft. Based on analysis of simulated incidents, APT-99 employs a multi-stage approach involving reconnaissance, phishing, lateral movement, and encrypted exfiltration. Blue teams should review this report to enhance detection and response capabilities against similar tactics.
llm_raw_response.full_report_text: APT-99 likely initiated operations by querying a paid threat intelligence feed to gather intelligence on the target's email infrastructure [T1597.001] and subsequently sent a phishing email disguised as a password reset request from the IT department to gather victim identity information [T1589]. The malware then queried the company's 'About Us' page to collect employee names for spear-phishing [T1589.003], while the threat actor uploaded a PowerShell backdoor script to a private GitHub repository for later retrieval [T1608]. In the next phase, Lumma Stealer was delivered through phishing emails containing malicious links [T1566.002], and the malware leveraged SCCM to run a PowerShell script that collected system information from connected workstations [T1072]. APT42 has used the PowerShell-based POWERPOST script to collect local account names from the victim machine [T1087.001], and the attacker used WinRM to remotely execute commands on the target Windows system [T1021.006]. LuminousMoth has used ARP spoofing to redirect a compromised machine to an actor-controlled website [T1557.002], and WARPWIRE can capture credentials submitted during the web logon process to access layer seven applications such as RDP [T1056.003]. The adversary used PowerShell to query IMAP servers for email metadata [T1114], and Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can change C2 servers [T1008]. Sibot communicated with its C2 server via HTTP GET requests [T1071.001], while OpenSSL encrypted the collected network topology maps before transmission [T1048.002]. Finally, the ransomware extracted sensitive_docs.zip from the network share before encryption [T1020]. System logs from the target environment showed routine backup processes and user login attempts, which were unrelated to the attack. The company, a mid-sized financial services firm, had recently updated its firewall policies, but this did not prevent the initial breach.
